lines.text: We just got lapped by an old lady in a walker.
Can I call my folks and tell them I won't be coming home... ever?
Would someone tell me what Mr. Shoop had planned for today?
Group sex. No, that's tomorrow. Today is independent study, right after our mid-morning nap.

[the class is watching "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre"]
Oh my God. What are you watching?
New film from the district, "Safe Use Of Power Tools".

[holds a box]
This just came... I don't want to know what's in here, do I?
Nope, probably not.
Hey, I remember you. Where have you been?
Bathroom.
For the last six weeks?
My zipper got stuck.
[Shoop is calling roll]
Francis Gremp?
Don't ever call me that, the name's "Chainsaw".
As in "Black and Decker"?
As in "Texas Massacre".
Our next field trip has to be to the beach.
We have to see Annamaria in a bikini. It's very important.
Tension-breaker. Had to be done.
This menstruation thing is a scam. Women are so lucky.

WHAT? Oh we're so lucky? You think having your period is a picnic in the park? First of all you're all PMSed out, and second you don't any room in your purse for your hairbrush because of all the damn mini pads. You are SO ignorant!
You passed and I failed! You asshole! How could you do that to me?
It was an accident. I'll take it again. I can fail, I know I can.
[about sobriety]
Reality is so unreal.
But it is a nice change.
True. Two thumbs up.
This menstruation thing? It's a scam! Women are so lucky.
Please take your seats.
Where should we take 'em?
You want us to study?
The thought did cross my mind.
Well, what's in it for us? What do we get out of it?
Literacy?
Your teacher was arrested for giving vodka to students.
You went to jail for us?
On roller skates.
[the classroom is the scene of a bloodbath]
What is wrong with you people?
It's just like you said Gills! We're psychopaths! Somebody better call the school nurse!
Where are my car keys?
There somewhere in this room. Right now you're ice cold.
So, you're all alone and you like young girls.
How do you spell "cat"?
I don't know!
How do you want your eggs? Fried, or scrambled?
I don't know. What are eggs?
Can anybody tell me why writing is important?
Because it's a form of communication.
Very good, it can also get you free stuff.
Free?
Free, I'm writing it down... here's how it works, we've all been ripped off, right? Pay phone steals your money... not enough cheese on your pizza...
My shades keep falling apart!
Consumer Against Faulty Eyewear.
You want me to lie? Okay.
Hi, I'd like to sign up for Lamaze classes.
Okay. How are Tuesday nights for you and your coach?
Perfect. But, I don't have a coach.
Well, what about the father?
Well, you see, that's sort of confusing. It's either David Lee Roth who's on tour or Sean Penn. And I'd really hate to upset Madonna.

[unamused]
Fill this out.
Are you sure you wanna do this?
great place to meet girls.
You know what we need Wonder Mutt?
[sticks his finger in jam jar with a peanut butter coated finger, and feeds it to Wonder Mutt]
Besides bread. We need a woman that can appreciate what we have to offer.

[Eakian shakes Larry awake]
Larry, what do you want?
Bed.
[falls back asleep]

[to Shoop]
Larry wants a bed.
I'm telling you, you gotta try these Pop Tarts.
No thanks, I'm sticking with the Chocodiles.

[to Chainsaw]
I think you're full of bull.
It's okay, you can say bullshit in here.

[trying to get out of teaching summer school]
I'm not a real teacher.
That's okay. They aren't real students.
Once a guy hits 18, it's all downhill.
But it's a lovely ride.
Alcohol kills brain cells. You lose one more and you're a talking monkey.

[reading Denise's complaint letter]
Shoop, this girl is dyslexic.
What?
This is serious. You've got to get her some help.
How did she go this long without anyone finding out?
She slipped through the system.
What happens when she gets out in the real world?

[reading call sheet]
Rhonda Altobello?
Here.
You went from Cs to Fs, what happened?

[stands up and pats her pregnant stomach]
Any other questions?

[embarrassed]
No.

[watching fireworks]
So pretty!
Alright, enough of this safe and sane garbage, it's time for dumb and dangerous!
Uh, can Rhonda and I be excused? She's having a baby.
You're having a baby?
[climbs over the desks to reach her]
Why didn't you say anything?
I wanted to finish my test.
[walks down the stairs towards the door]
Can I get you anything, hot water, a doctor?

[laughs]
Get out of my way.
Get out of your way, I can do that.
[to school security]
Carmine, get out of her way!

[on the beach]
What's it like being pregnant?
Bizarre. My body's out of control.
I think you look great.
Sure, in the dark.

[shakes head]
No.

[Chainsaw pours a large fish tank on the couch to put out a fire]
My fish!
How many were there?
Just one.
Field trips to the beach, drinking on the beach, a bed in your classroom, a screening of Texas Chainsaw Massacre 1... quite a summer, Mr. Shoop.
I tried to keep it interesting.
I have his dismissal ready for your signature, sir.
Before I sign anything, I understand there are some people waiting to speak on Mr. Shoop's behalf.
Really?
Come in.
[opens the door to Shoop's students and their parents and guardians]
Mr. Kelban, you're not actually going to listen to these delinquents?
No, I'm going to listen to their parents. I'm Principal Kelban. Is there a spokesperson here?
I guess I am. I'm Howard Gremp.
You're Chainsaw's father. Interesting boy.
No, you can say it. He's a lunatic.
Dad...

Six weeks ago, I thought he had the IQ of a salad bar. His only interest in life was to make people sick. I my mother came to dinner, he would give the dog a third eye or an extra leg. Because of him, we stopped having kids. You can imagine the feeling when I saw him studying. The wife and I almost burst into tears.
David was doing his homework, too.
It makes sense, they share the same brain.
Not only did Mr. Shoop get my daughter to read, he taught her to drive.
He showed Kevin there's more to life than football. I'm not sure I agree, but it's possible.
This man should not be teaching. The proof is right here in these test results. Look for yourself, Mr. Shoop. Passing is 70; average score here was 63. They failed.

[looks at the results]
That is not true, Mr. Gills.
You mean we passed?
No, not all of you, but that's not what's important here. Larry went from an 18 to a 51!
If I'd only seen you strip a week sooner.
from a 29 to a 43 and she gave birth.
Isn't childbirth grounds for a makeup test?
It always has been.
This woman thing never fails.
a 51 to a 74.
I passed! I am an Eakian, Grams!
All right, Eaker!
no previous test score because you ditched every test, but a 38.
Honey, that's terrific!
We'll get 'em next time.
Kevin, from a 48 to a 75!
Yeah, I'm back on the team!
[Kevin and his did share football shouts and hug]
from a 26 to a 70.
I passed!
You made it!
You passed? You passed and I failed, asshole! How could you do that to me?
It was an accident. I'll take it again, I can fail, I know it.
Pam went from a 53 to an 82.
Was that the highest?
Well, almost. That guy who spent six weeks in the bathroom got a 91. But look, there's more going on here than test scores and grades. You all worked hard and improved.
And that's very nice, Mr. Shoop. The point here is that we are here to discuss Mr. Shoop's flagrant violation of school policies.
Hold it, Gills. According to my numbers, the average scores have increased from 28 to 63. That's 125% improvement. Now that's teaching. Mr. Shoop, I'm granting you tenure.
